messageBody:
Moira O'Brien scripsit:

> Another point I meant to comment on was
> the use of letter "t" in the middle of words. Personally, I will
> ALWAYS use "t" wherever it is spelled
> unless it is followed by a consonant. But is is becoming
> more and more common in England, especially in London, to drop the T
> altogether except at the begining of words (and even then in lazy speak).

It's not really dropped altogether, it's replaced by a sound called
a glottal stop, written [?] in IPA (or rather, in ASCII-ized IPA).
All accents use at least some glottalization in words like "bottle"
([bQ?l] or [bA?l] as the case may be). The evidence that /t/ doesn't
fully vanish is that "kits" [kI?s] and "kiss" [kIs] don't sound alike.

So the phoneme /t/ now has two allophones in many "estuarine" accents, [t]
and [?]. This is nothing unusual, and doesn't have to be recorded in QS,
as [t] is only used in the onset of a syllable and [?] only in the coda
(the consonants before and after the vowel respectively).

The American case is more problematic, because the intervocalic version
of /t/ is [d], the same sound used for /d/. (Note carefully that sounds
are in square brackets, abstract phonemes in slashes.) We say that
the /t/ vs. /d/ distinction is neutralized in that context. Similarly,
the distinction between /E/ and /I/ is neutralized in Southern American
before /m/ and /n/.

Deciding what to do about neutralizations in QS is the same issue as
deciding what to do about mergers: a neutralization is just a merger
that happens only in certain contexts.

--
John Cowan http://ccil.org/~cowan cowan@...
[P]olice in many lands are now complaining that local arrestees are insisting
on having their Miranda rights read to them, just like perps in American TV
cop shows. When it's explained to them that they are in a different country,
where those rights do not exist, they become outraged. --Neal Stephenson
